Donald Ervin Knuth

Biography

Donald Ervin Knuth is a professor in Stanford University and a computer scientist.He is the author of “The Art of Computer programming", a set of books that talks about algorithms and algorithms analisys. Published in 1968 this collection of books is composed of 6 volumes, at the beginning he wrote just 1 volume, but he realised it wasn’t enough to explain all he wanted to.
In 1978 Knuth is became the creator of Tex, a language suitable for writing professional informatic and mathematic texts.
Knuth is born in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, and he took his matematic degree at Case Institute of technology.
In 1963 Knuth, under the supervision of Marshal Hall, he got a doctorate in mathematics at California Institute of technology, were he began working as an associated.
While studying Knuth began working to the IBM 650, which was the first mass produced computer in the world. Using his ingenious ways to solve problems, after reading the computer's manual, Knuth rewrited the compiler and assembly code for the machine used in the school he was studying, because he thought he could have done it better.
In 1992 Knuth withdrew from the regular commit of research to keep writing The Art of Computer Science publishing the first three volumes in 2004.

Influence

The first three books that Knuth published had an important impact and helped many people to build knowledge on these books.
In 1974 Knuth has taken the A. M. Turing award for a big contribution on the field of design of programming languages and analysis of algorithms, and particularly for his important contributions to “The Art of Computer Programming” thanks to his collection of known books. The collections of algorithms, technique and the most important theory in all the books served as an significant influence in computer science.
Given the many awards received, all the work done in influencing computer science, and his ingenious ways to solve problems, Knuth has been called the "father of the analysis of algorithms".

Turing Award 1974

In memory of A.M. Turing
